pros:
- Challenging, Career-Defining Project
- Talented Coworkers
- Employee Discount
cons:
I started here super optimistic to be working for one of the most recognizable brands in the world. The experience has only gone downhill. I had a great manager who advocated for me and was my champion. Despite that, and several years of stellar performance reviews, HR would not heed my manager’s recommendation for advancement.  This situation was not unique to my position as several of my peers still face this challenge after being high performers for serval years. Advancement and promotion here is a complete mystery. They do not invest in their talent nor see people as their most valuable asset. Discarded at random, during good times, your job will never be safe at this company. Leadership is nonexistent in this place, which is so contradictory for a company that prides itself on team and inclusion. Don’t be fooled. NIKE is a master manipulator and expert image crafter. Internally, moral has never been lower as we close in on month 5 of the largest layoff in history.  We’re not even laying off people because business is hurting - we’re laying of people because our executive team built an org that was too big - and now those people who had nothing to do with creating the “matrix”- our internal organization - are paying for it.  So top line:
- no advancement / career growth
- systemic lack of leadership 
- does not value people
- layoffs every 3 years (in good times)
- masters of manipulation (internal and external)

pros:
- The cool factor. Cool brand with the opportunity to see some amazing athletes and be part of a great banding/advertising machine. 
- Salary offer is competitive, especially for the work you are asked to do (see cons)
- If you work at the main campus  in Beaverton, you'll have a very nice work environment with great sports facilities  + children's day care on site. 
- If you love sneakers, the employee discount is pretty sweet. 
- Money does not seem to be an objection. Projects etc are always ample funded and events/workshops are plenty and very well catered.
cons:
- When applying, be aware of the title inflation.  From a responsibility and workload perspective a director at Nike is equivalent to a Sr. Manager in other large multinational corporations.  (However,  they will pay Director level.)   
- Outside hires tend to get  "benched" for at least 1 year before being allowed to make significant contributions.   If you are a senior manager and want to hit the ground running, Nike is not for you. 
- Things get done based on cultivating personal relations and talking things trough till all parties + their grandmothers agree (even if they functionally have nothing to do with an action).   
- There is a bit of a locker room frat culture.  Hanging out and drinking is considered essential for building relations which are critical for (career) success.  It is not how good you are at your job, it's about how well you are liked.

review_title: Highs and Lows but overall excellent
pros:
Flat hierarchy and opportunities to grow (takes time and dedication though)
Work hard and get rewarded
We play hard too
If an opportunity to travel comes your way the experience is amazing and much more than just another business trip
Great Corporate Culture, smart, innovative and exciting
Proud of Girl Effect and other Global "do the right thing"initiatives we support
Sport and team orientated
Flexible hours, work for home and other work life balance technologies available
Excellent facilities, 3 canteens, full gym and major sporting facilities, 1 hour a day built in to sport and flexible timing
Focus more on results than being just seen to be attending
Team spirit normally high and very supportive
cons:
As mentioned by others;networking can either help you along or get in your way
If Snr Management are aligned to your work it is a dream, but an individual or group can stifle or kill good work or cause us to lose talented people, which is a shame as it is NOT in our culture to lose the best but bad luck and you lose time moving sideways to get around the bad apple (low accountability can be part of the problem but employee feedback technology is on the way to tackle this)
Image is off a fast track rise through the ranks but reality is a normal US Corporation, it takes time and hard work and people can get stuck
Long hours and not high payers, but if you enjoy the environment then this is not as bad as it sounds (non-$ compensation is good and leavers often say they ultimately miss this when chasing higher $'s)

review_title: Frat-boy culture getting on my last nerve
pros: Great co-workers. Some nice perks. Interesting work. Awesome campus. Most people really like working here. Summer hours program is amazing. People are really passionate about what they are doing. Lots of advancement opportunities IF you look and act like a high school cheerleader or a drunken frat-boy.
cons: Disrespectful, ageist, sexist, entitled, pampered and selfish upper management. review_title: It was the best of times...it was the worst of times
pros: Amazing brand, fantastic product (which you and your family get a huge discount on) athletes show up on campus, fantastic work environment, great coworkers. 2 gyms like you've never seen that you can go to during work hours (where else can you swim @ work?). Flexible work arrangements (telecommute, flex time), stock + bonuses + profit sharing + employee stock purchase program are consistently profitable and good investments. Work can be inspiriring and company always "does the right thing" environmentally. Great vacation/sick policy.
cons: Unclear career pathing - where do I go from here? Once you're in the company, you're on your own to manage your own career. Limited training opportunities for growth. Often times biz units are under resourced, causing employees to have to work long hours for months at a time. You are always expected to produce no matter what - if that means killing yourself, so be it. Promotions are handed out based on who you know not what you do - frequently the most qualified person for the job is passed over to give the management role to a less qualified or deserving candidate. Compensation is low for the area and industry (but this is alleviated by many of the perks).

review_title: Good place to work if you have out of work activities
pros: Huge nice team and plenty of age ranges working within the store.  Can build a great friendship network there. Discount is great as well,  free uniform every 3months or so. Cool working environment (forever making cool changes to the store) The chance to get involved with amazing campaigns. Fun team building excercises at the start of most shifts. Bonus schemes. Always something fun happening. They love inclusion!
cons: Managers can go on a little power trip from time to time. Feels like a school run environment at times. Problems can sometimes take time to fix. You sometimes need to have a strong backbone and tolerance due to the amount of different personalities that can work there and the types of consumers you'll be dealing with. Only offers two contract types (there use to be 4 in total). Relies too much on customer feedback to measure an individuals performance at work (based on the chance a customer remembering to fill out a survey once they've left the store) therefore a lot of workers can feel overlooked. If taken off of the bonus scheme for any reason you can feel demotivated to help the store reach much pushed targets. Shifts are done electronically, if you can't do a shift you have to find someone to swap with which is extremely hard at times.
